newsitem.title: ITALY: Albania poll distorted by fear - Democrat leader.
newsitem.headline: Albania poll distorted by fear - Democrat leader.

text.p: Albania's general election took place in a climate of terror and was marred by irregularities which distorted the result, chairman of the defeated Democratic Party Tritan Shehu was quoted on Tuesday as saying.
"There were serious irregularities," Shehu was quoted as telling Italian weekly magazine La Discussione in an interview to be published in full on Wednesday.

"In 30 of the seats in the south we weren't even able to present our candidates. We were completely blocked. He said his party had accepted the result "only so as to avoid confrontation and violence".
"We don't consider it to be a real result but we put the interests of the country before those of the party.
"We had 25 percent of the vote to their 47 percent. I know that is not the Albanian reality because the election took place in a climate of violence, of terror..."
Shehu's Democrats were ousted by Albania's ex-communist Socialists in a poll described by international monitors on Tuesday as "acceptable given the prevailing circumstances".
The Socialists and their allies look set for a two-thirds majority in parliament as a result of the June 29 and July 6 voting, which followed months of armed anarchy.
Shehu said the election had handed power back to rulers from the impoverished Balkan country's hardline Communist past.
"The future depends on what the Socialists do," he said.

"Their victory has brought people from the old regime back into power, people who have committed crimes, people who, until a little time ago, were going around terrorising others, people who, I'm sure, don't have a democratic vision of public life.
